summary: This is a certificate of authenticity from AT&T's Global Legal Demand Center, responding to a legal demand dated April 5, 2019, regarding telephone records. It certifies that attached records are true duplicates made in the ordinary course of business, intended to satisfy Federal Rules of Evidence 902(11) and 902(13).

persons.name: Nicholas DeRoy
persons.context: He attests under penalty of perjury to the authenticity of telephone records produced by AT&T in response to a legal demand, certifying they are true duplicates made in the ordinary course of business.

events.title: Legal Demand Issued
events.description: A legal demand was issued, likely from law enforcement or a legal entity, requesting telephone records from AT&T.

events.title: Certificate of Authenticity Signed
events.description: Nicholas DeRoy signed the certificate of authenticity for AT&T records, attesting to their validity under Federal Rules of Evidence.

locations: 11760 US Highway 1 Suite 600, North Palm Beach, FL 33408-3029
keyFacts: AT&T's Global Legal Demand Center produced records in response to a legal demand dated April 5, 2019, related to case number 2712626.
Nicholas DeRoy, an AT&T Legal Compliance Analyst, certified the authenticity of the records under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1746.
The certification states the records were made at or near the time of the events, kept in the ordinary course of business, and are true duplicates of originals.
The document is intended to satisfy Federal Rules of Evidence 902(11) and 902(13) for the admissibility of domestic business records.
The cover sheet notes that phone numbers listed may not have been assigned to AT&T for the entire time frame but could have roamed on its network or interacted with AT&T subscribers.
